body.p: (Private)
Rev & Dear Friend

In my last letter
I informed you of a contempla
-ted movement among our people
having in view the union of
the two congregations—in order
to secure better religious &
educational advantages for
both adults & children

I was unable to give you
then the real objects, entertained
by those most zealous for the
proposed consolidation. Since
the meeting of the committees
and their preliminary reports
to both Kabals—the real
intentions have become maini
-fest and these I propose
to make known to you.

Let me premise by saying the
present condition of both Kabals
educationally considered is deplora
-ble, at least in the light of the
advanced progress of the Age.

Now it is proposed by the zealots
to build a new Synagogue—first
disposing of one or both of the
existing structures & have its
interior constructed for family
pews—for male & female—to adopt
a new minhag—engage a reform
preacher & in a word go the whole
figure a la Dr Wise.

In the limits of a letter I cannot
give you an adequate idea of the
wishes & intentions of the so called
reformers. Let me say that a
very large number if not quite
a majority of the members of
both societies are ready & anxious

to adopt these views & projects
unless speedily enlightened as to
their apostasy. The only saving
clause to us for I class myself
among those who will resist
to the utmost this wholesale
ann system of innovation to
use no harsher term—is that
if a majority of both societies
determine to adopt these doc-
-trines we can restrain them
from selling the property as we
own & possess in good title
seats forever in the respective buildings & they do not propose
to allow us for these any com-
pensation or return either whole
or in part in the new edifice.

I have looked up the legal
authorities on this point besides
taking the benefit of counsel.

Now I am willing & ready to surrender
all real & personal interest I own in the
synagogue & unite with the other society
provided—there shall be no overreacting
and departure from the limits of enlight
-ened orthodoxy.

I am in favor of a
preacher of enlightened views—a school-
of doing away with certain customs
(mere forms)—of repetition of prayers—
and of other sensible modifications,
but I decline to reject the belief in
a personal messiah & the resurrection
of the body. These I hold as funda
-mental principles of our faith that
cannot be abolished or abandoned.

Now with reference to Pews—
I believe neither the Pentateuch nor Prophets speak
advisedly on this point—the only reason
for the seperation of the sexes I have
ever heard advanced & have entertained
myself have been with reference to cleanli
-ness & the reverse at certain periods
in the other sex. Understand me
though—that while I say this to you

privately
I maintain publicly an observance of the old
custom that is I have already done
so in more than one speech on the
subject. Now I want your advice
on this point and arguments to
sustain my public position for my
private conviction rather favor the
mingling of both sexes in the Synagogue
on an equality. It is true—it is assim
-ilates in form to Christian mode
of worship—but ? devotion
if only apparent is not wanting
in the appearance of their Congre
-gations. Give me some good solid
reasons or law why they should not
sit together. I wish it was in
my power to have the benefit
of your society for at least two
hours—that we might go over
all these points. I stand in
need of confirmation of assistance
of counsel of authorities etc etc.

My mind misgives on many points
advanced in favor of change. I
see much that might be adopted
with benefit—much that would
cause Israel to depart eventually
from its ancient faith.

The reformers in our Congrega-
-tion are Solomon Hyman—Alex
Schwab—Mosely Ezekiel—Solomon
Mann & Messrs Steiner—Bloch—
Platt & Nusbaum. Those who
oppose these besides myself are
Messrs Ga Davis F I. Cohen Jacob Cohen
D Cauffman C & A Loeb. C Koeh
E. Cohen which I A Isaacs B. Shribe
& M Liebenthal are not to be relied
on for anything.

Will you break away
from your numerous duties for an
hour & give me the benefit of your

counsel & experience. Oh, would it
were I could see you. I study the
law constantly but my duties will
not allow me time to grasp hold of
all I could wish to explore & examine
& determine & then being all alone
I fear to rely singly on my own judge-
-ment lest it lead me astray.
A few years more study will de-
-termine my mind but these years
must be directed in a measure
by better wisdom than that
which now falls to my share.

Please write me speedily
& greatly oblige
Your very true & Sincere friend
